### addStackMapLiveVars() {#a21f33b0949c9004250a9978f1a5d3b3d}

<MemberDefinition
  prototype={<>static void addStackMapLiveVars (<a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/target/lib/target/aarch64/aarch64promoteconstant-cpp/#a90f8350fecae261c25be85d38b451bff">const</a> <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/callbase">CallBase</a> &amp; Call, unsigned StartIdx, <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/target/lib/target/aarch64/aarch64promoteconstant-cpp/#a90f8350fecae261c25be85d38b451bff">const</a> <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/sdloc">SDLoc</a> &amp; DL, <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/smallvectorimpl">SmallVectorImpl</a>&lt; <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/sdvalue">SDValue</a> &gt; &amp; Ops, <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/selectiondagbuilder">SelectionDAGBuilder</a> &amp; Builder)</>}
  labels = {["static"]}>
Add a stack map intrinsic call&#39;s live variable operands to a stackmap or patchpoint target node&#39;s operand list.

Constants are converted to TargetConstants purely as an optimization to avoid constant materialization and register allocation.

FrameIndex operands are converted to TargetFrameIndex so that ISEL does not generate addess computation nodes, and so FinalizeISel can convert the TargetFrameIndex into a DirectMemRefOp StackMap location. This avoids address materialization and register allocation, but may also be required for correctness. If a StackMap (or PatchPoint) intrinsic directly uses an alloca in the entry block, then the runtime may assume that the alloca&#39;s StackMap location can be read immediately after compilation and that the location is valid at any point during execution (this is similar to the assumption made by the llvm.gcroot intrinsic). If the alloca&#39;s location were only available in a register, then the runtime would need to trap when execution reaches the StackMap in order to read the alloca&#39;s location.

Definition at line <a href="#l10631">10631</a> of file <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/codegen/lib/codegen/selectiondag/selectiondagbuilder-cpp">SelectionDAGBuilder.cpp</a>.
</MemberDefinition>

<MemberDefinition
  prototype={<>static void findUnwindDestinations (<a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/functionloweringinfo">FunctionLoweringInfo</a> &amp; FuncInfo, <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/target/lib/target/aarch64/aarch64promoteconstant-cpp/#a90f8350fecae261c25be85d38b451bff">const</a> <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/basicblock">BasicBlock</a> &#42; EHPadBB, <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/branchprobability">BranchProbability</a> Prob, <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/smallvectorimpl">SmallVectorImpl</a>&lt; std::pair&lt; <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/machinebasicblock">MachineBasicBlock</a> &#42;, <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/branchprobability">BranchProbability</a> &gt; &gt; &amp; UnwindDests)</>}
  labels = {["static"]}>
When an invoke or a cleanupret unwinds to the next EH pad, there are many places it could ultimately go.

In the IR, we have a single unwind destination, but in the machine CFG, we enumerate all the possible blocks. This function skips over imaginary basic blocks that hold catchswitch instructions, and finds all the &quot;real&quot; machine basic block destinations. As those destinations may not be successors of EHPadBB, here we also calculate the edge probability to those destinations. The passed-in Prob is the edge probability to EHPadBB.

<Link id="l00138" /><CodeLine lineNumber="138"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// Limit the width of DAG chains. This is important in general to prevent</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00139" /><CodeLine lineNumber="139"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// DAG-based analysis from blowing up. For example, alias analysis and</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00140" /><CodeLine lineNumber="140"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// load clustering may not complete in reasonable time. It is difficult to</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00141" /><CodeLine lineNumber="141"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// recognize and avoid this situation within each individual analysis, and</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00142" /><CodeLine lineNumber="142"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// future analyses are likely to have the same behavior. Limiting DAG width is</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00143" /><CodeLine lineNumber="143"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// the safe approach and will be especially important with global DAGs.</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00144" /><CodeLine lineNumber="144"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">//</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00145" /><CodeLine lineNumber="145"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// MaxParallelChains default is arbitrarily high to avoid affecting</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00146" /><CodeLine lineNumber="146"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// optimization, but could be lowered to improve compile time. Any ld-ld-st-st</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00147" /><CodeLine lineNumber="147"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// sequence over this should have been converted to llvm.memcpy by the</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00148" /><CodeLine lineNumber="148"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// frontend. It is easy to induce this behavior with .ll code such as:</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00149" /><CodeLine lineNumber="149"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// %buffer = alloca &#91;4096 x i8&#93;</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00150" /><CodeLine lineNumber="150"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// %data = load &#91;4096 x i8&#93;&#42; %argPtr</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00151" /><CodeLine lineNumber="151"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// store &#91;4096 x i8&#93; %data, &#91;4096 x i8&#93;&#42; %buffer</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>

<Link id="l02034" /><CodeLine lineNumber="2034"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// In wasm EH, even though a catchpad may not catch an exception if a tag does</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l02035" /><CodeLine lineNumber="2035"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// not match, it is OK to add only the first unwind destination catchpad to the</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l02036" /><CodeLine lineNumber="2036"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// successors, because there will be at least one invoke instruction within the</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l02037" /><CodeLine lineNumber="2037"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// catch scope that points to the next unwind destination, if one exists, so</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l02038" /><CodeLine lineNumber="2038"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// CFGSort cannot mess up with BB sorting order.</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l02039" /><CodeLine lineNumber="2039"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// (All catchpads with &#39;catch (type)&#39; clauses have a &#39;llvm.rethrow&#39; intrinsic</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l02040" /><CodeLine lineNumber="2040"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// call within them, and catchpads only consisting of &#39;catch (...)&#39; have a</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l02041" /><CodeLine lineNumber="2041"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// &#39;&#95;&#95;cxa&#95;end&#95;catch&#39; call within them, both of which generate invokes in case</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l02042" /><CodeLine lineNumber="2042"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// the next unwind destination exists, i.e., the next unwind destination is not</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l02043" /><CodeLine lineNumber="2043"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// the caller.)</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l02044" /><CodeLine lineNumber="2044"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">//</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l02045" /><CodeLine lineNumber="2045"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// Having at most one EH pad successor is also simpler and helps later</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l02046" /><CodeLine lineNumber="2046"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// transformations.</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l02047" /><CodeLine lineNumber="2047"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">//</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l02048" /><CodeLine lineNumber="2048"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// For example,</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l02049" /><CodeLine lineNumber="2049"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// current:</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l02050" /><CodeLine lineNumber="2050"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">//   invoke void @foo to ... unwind label %catch.dispatch</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l02051" /><CodeLine lineNumber="2051"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// catch.dispatch:</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l02052" /><CodeLine lineNumber="2052"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">//   %0 = catchswitch within ... &#91;label %catch.start&#93; unwind label %next</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l02053" /><CodeLine lineNumber="2053"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// catch.start:</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l02054" /><CodeLine lineNumber="2054"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">//   ...</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l02055" /><CodeLine lineNumber="2055"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">//   ... in this BB or some other child BB dominated by this BB there will be an</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l02056" /><CodeLine lineNumber="2056"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">//   invoke that points to &#39;next&#39; BB as an unwind destination</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l02057" /><CodeLine lineNumber="2057"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">//</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l02058" /><CodeLine lineNumber="2058"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// next: ; We don&#39;t need to add this to &#39;current&#39; BB&#39;s successor</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l02059" /><CodeLine lineNumber="2059"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">//   ...</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l02060" /><CodeLine lineNumber="2060" lineLink="#ac48ad402cb64f4c6bd6bb7158013a7be"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="keyword">static</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"> </Highlight><Highlight kind="keywordtype">void</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"> <a href="#ac48ad402cb64f4c6bd6bb7158013a7be">findWasmUnwindDestinations</a>(</Highlight></CodeLine>

<Link id="l04845" /><CodeLine lineNumber="4845"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// Get a uniform base for the Gather/Scatter intrinsic.</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l04846" /><CodeLine lineNumber="4846"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// The first argument of the Gather/Scatter intrinsic is a vector of pointers.</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l04847" /><CodeLine lineNumber="4847"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// We try to represent it as a base pointer + vector of indices.</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l04848" /><CodeLine lineNumber="4848"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// Usually, the vector of pointers comes from a &#39;getelementptr&#39; instruction.</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l04849" /><CodeLine lineNumber="4849"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// The first operand of the GEP may be a single pointer or a vector of pointers</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l04850" /><CodeLine lineNumber="4850"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// Example:</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l04851" /><CodeLine lineNumber="4851"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">//   %gep.ptr = getelementptr i32, &lt;8 x i32&#42;&gt; %vptr, &lt;8 x i32&gt; %ind</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l04852" /><CodeLine lineNumber="4852"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">//  or</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l04853" /><CodeLine lineNumber="4853"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">//   %gep.ptr = getelementptr i32, i32&#42; %ptr,        &lt;8 x i32&gt; %ind</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l04854" /><CodeLine lineNumber="4854"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// %res = call &lt;8 x i32&gt; @llvm.masked.gather.v8i32(&lt;8 x i32&#42;&gt; %gep.ptr, ..</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l04855" /><CodeLine lineNumber="4855"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">//</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l04856" /><CodeLine lineNumber="4856"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// When the first GEP operand is a single pointer - it is the uniform base we</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l04857" /><CodeLine lineNumber="4857"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// are looking for. If first operand of the GEP is a splat vector - we</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l04858" /><CodeLine lineNumber="4858"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// extract the splat value and use it as a uniform base.</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l04859" /><CodeLine lineNumber="4859"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// In all other cases the function returns &#39;false&#39;.</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>

<Link id="l10032" /><CodeLine lineNumber="10032"><Highlight kind="normal">    </Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// In Linux PIC model, there are 4 cases about value/label addressing:</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l10033" /><CodeLine lineNumber="10033"><Highlight kind="normal">    </Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">//</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l10034" /><CodeLine lineNumber="10034"><Highlight kind="normal">    </Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// 1: Function call or Label jmp inside the module.</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l10035" /><CodeLine lineNumber="10035"><Highlight kind="normal">    </Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// 2: Data access (such as global variable, static variable) inside module.</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l10036" /><CodeLine lineNumber="10036"><Highlight kind="normal">    </Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// 3: Function call or Label jmp outside the module.</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l10037" /><CodeLine lineNumber="10037"><Highlight kind="normal">    </Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// 4: Data access (such as global variable) outside the module.</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l10038" /><CodeLine lineNumber="10038"><Highlight kind="normal">    </Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">//</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l10039" /><CodeLine lineNumber="10039"><Highlight kind="normal">    </Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// Due to current llvm inline asm architecture designed to not &quot;recognize&quot;</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l10040" /><CodeLine lineNumber="10040"><Highlight kind="normal">    </Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// the asm code, there are quite troubles for us to treat mem addressing</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l10041" /><CodeLine lineNumber="10041"><Highlight kind="normal">    </Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// differently for same value/adress used in different instuctions.</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l10042" /><CodeLine lineNumber="10042"><Highlight kind="normal">    </Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// For example, in pic model, call a func may in plt way or direclty</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l10043" /><CodeLine lineNumber="10043"><Highlight kind="normal">    </Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// pc-related, but lea/mov a function adress may use got.</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l10044" /><CodeLine lineNumber="10044"><Highlight kind="normal">    </Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">//</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l10045" /><CodeLine lineNumber="10045"><Highlight kind="normal">    </Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// Here we try to &quot;recognize&quot; function call for the case 1 and case 3 in</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l10046" /><CodeLine lineNumber="10046"><Highlight kind="normal">    </Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// inline asm. And try to adjust the constraint for them.</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l10047" /><CodeLine lineNumber="10047"><Highlight kind="normal">    </Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">//</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l10048" /><CodeLine lineNumber="10048"><Highlight kind="normal">    </Highlight><Highlight kind="comment">// TODO: Due to current inline asm didn&#39;t encourage to jmp to the outsider</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>

<Link id="l10614" /><CodeLine lineNumber="10614"><Highlight kind="comment">/// Add a stack map intrinsic call&#39;s live variable operands to a stackmap</Highlight></CodeLine>

<Link id="l10616" /><CodeLine lineNumber="10616"><Highlight kind="comment">///</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l10617" /><CodeLine lineNumber="10617"><Highlight kind="comment">/// Constants are converted to TargetConstants purely as an optimization to</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l10618" /><CodeLine lineNumber="10618"><Highlight kind="comment">/// avoid constant materialization and register allocation.</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l10619" /><CodeLine lineNumber="10619"><Highlight kind="comment">///</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l10620" /><CodeLine lineNumber="10620"><Highlight kind="comment">/// FrameIndex operands are converted to TargetFrameIndex so that ISEL does not</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l10621" /><CodeLine lineNumber="10621"><Highlight kind="comment">/// generate addess computation nodes, and so FinalizeISel can convert the</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l10622" /><CodeLine lineNumber="10622"><Highlight kind="comment">/// TargetFrameIndex into a DirectMemRefOp StackMap location. This avoids</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l10623" /><CodeLine lineNumber="10623"><Highlight kind="comment">/// address materialization and register allocation, but may also be required</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l10624" /><CodeLine lineNumber="10624"><Highlight kind="comment">/// for correctness. If a StackMap (or PatchPoint) intrinsic directly uses an</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l10625" /><CodeLine lineNumber="10625"><Highlight kind="comment">/// alloca in the entry block, then the runtime may assume that the alloca&#39;s</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l10626" /><CodeLine lineNumber="10626"><Highlight kind="comment">/// StackMap location can be read immediately after compilation and that the</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l10627" /><CodeLine lineNumber="10627"><Highlight kind="comment">/// location is valid at any point during execution (this is similar to the</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l10628" /><CodeLine lineNumber="10628"><Highlight kind="comment">/// assumption made by the llvm.gcroot intrinsic). If the alloca&#39;s location were</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l10629" /><CodeLine lineNumber="10629"><Highlight kind="comment">/// only available in a register, then the runtime would need to trap when</Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l10630" /><CodeLine lineNumber="10630"><Highlight kind="comment">/// execution reaches the StackMap in order to read the alloca&#39;s location.</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight></CodeLine>
<Link id="l10631" /><CodeLine lineNumber="10631" lineLink="#a21f33b0949c9004250a9978f1a5d3b3d"><Highlight kind="normal"></Highlight><Highlight kind="keyword">static</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"> </Highlight><Highlight kind="keywordtype">void</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"> <a href="#a21f33b0949c9004250a9978f1a5d3b3d">addStackMapLiveVars</a>(</Highlight><Highlight kind="keyword">const</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"> <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/callbase">CallBase</a> &amp;<a href="/docs/api/groups/arcopt/#ga9c9cf6ad55eb23d77d083a184e416c09">Call</a>, </Highlight><Highlight kind="keywordtype">unsigned</Highlight><Highlight kind="normal"> StartIdx,</Highlight></CodeLine>
